baseline_groups.claim_summary: EITC information treatment has no statistically significant average effect on EITC amounts (d_fdeic) in the full sample of ~43,000 H&R Block clients.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3 Col 1: d_fdeic ~ treat | No controls | Full sample. The only spec marked is_baseline=True. Coefficient $24 (p=0.099 standard, p=0.100 permutation). This is the headline null result: information provision has a marginally insignificant average effect. The paper notes this null is explained by offsetting effects among complying vs non-complying tax preparers.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Among clients of 'complying' tax preparers (goodtax==1), the EITC information treatment significantly increased EITC amounts by $58-67.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3 Cols 1-2: d_fdeic ~ treat | goodtax==1 subsample. This is the paper's central positive finding. The treatment increases EITC amounts by $67 without controls (p=0.003) and $58 with controls (p=0.007). Robust to permutation inference (p=0.002 and p=0.0045 respectively). The complier subsample is defined by above-median tax preparer effects on the share of clients with income in the EITC-maximizing range.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The differential treatment effect between complying and non-complying tax preparers (goodtax x treat interaction) on EITC amounts is large and significant.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3 Cols 1-2: d_fdeic ~ good_treat (interaction term) | Full sample with goodtax interaction. The differential effect of $90-95 between complying and non-complying preparers is significant (p=0.007-0.009) and robust to permutation inference (p=0.006-0.007). This is the key result establishing that treatment heterogeneity is driving the average null result.

global_notes: Paper is 'Teaching the Tax Code' by Chetty & Saez (AEJ: Applied, 2013). The underlying microdata (ts0708_total.dta) is confidential/proprietary H&R Block data, so no new specifications could be run. All 130 specifications were extracted from the permutation results file (coeff_final.dta), which stores coefficients and p-values for 24 KS tests and 106 OLS regressions. Standard errors and sample sizes are unavailable. The 40 specifications with clearly identified outcomes and designs (reg_1 through reg_66, kst_1 through kst_24) can be classified with high confidence. The remaining 40 specs (reg_67 through reg_106) have unidentified outcomes ('outcome_spec_67' etc.) because they come from unlabeled columns in the permutation file; their exact specifications cannot be determined from the available code and data. These are classified as non-core with reduced confidence. The paper's central finding is that treatment effects are concentrated among complying tax preparers, not that there is a significant full-sample effect.
